title: Do you support companies that are environmentally friendly? - Quora

response.answer_text: Very difficult to answer this question. I live in a civilisation style that has made me dependent on the products of many different companies. I can’t exist without many of these products. There is no easy alternative to this existence. I could pack my bags and live in the bush but I don’t know how to and have no experience to do so. I don’t know the difference between an edible or poisonous berry or mushroom. It’s something that I’ve never been taught. I still drive a car, use my home electrical appliances and warm my house. I fly to places for a holiday, eat processed food and fresh produce prepared for me and I wear clothing. These things are prepared or manufactured in industrial complexes that use all sorts of machinery and consume a load of energy, much of which comes from fossil fuels. When I’m not feeling well I see my doctor and if things are bad an ambulance comes and takes me to a sophisticated and high tech environment called a hospital. The skilled medical staff give me an excellent opportunity to survive and continue my life for which I am extremely thankful. I am a slave to all these components of the industrialised system of civilisation just like everyone else. We are all in this together. I support companies that are environmentally friendly but they also can only be environmentally friendly to a point. They are also slaves to this system. There are no companies that are totally environmentally friendly. The first time a company turns on a light or flushes a toilet the company can no longer be considered environmentally friendly in the absolute meaning of the term.
Prove to me that any company is environmentally friendly and I will support them. The truth is that companies are profit friendly. The bigger they grow, the less they care about the environment.
Sure if they make something useful, durable, repairable, and if their claims are not just marketing gimmicks.

Whenever possible. Most plastic, like the case of this laptop, is made from petroleum, but it doesn’t have to. There are plenty of non fossil based polymers that could be as good or better. 'Infinitely' recyclable polymer shows practical properties of plastics
